questions.text: A small baby 2 months of age was presented with watering of eye. There is also photophobia. Which of the following is not a cause related to his symptoms
questions.solution:
Congenital Dacryocystitis (Dacryocystitis Neonatorum)

  • Inflammation of the lacrimal sac in newborns, caused by congenital blockage of the nasolacrimal duct (NLD).
  • Occurs in ~30% of newborns, commonly due to membranous occlusion near the valve of Hasner.

Etiology:

  • Membranous occlusion at the lower end of NLD (near Hasner's valve) is the most common cause.
  • Other causes: epithelial debris, membranous occlusion at the upper end, complete non-canalization, or rarely, bony occlusion.
  • Common bacteria: Staphylococci, Pneumococci, Streptococci.

Clinical Features:

  1. Epiphora: Watery eyes, starting after 7 days of birth, followed by mucopurulent discharge.
  2. Regurgitation Test: Positive when pressure on the lacrimal sac causes purulent discharge from the lower punctum.
  3. Swelling: May appear on the sac area.

Differential Diagnosis:

  • Ophthalmia neonatorum
  • Congenital glaucoma

Complications (if untreated):

  • Recurrent conjunctivitis
  • Acute/chronic dacryocystitis
  • Lacrimal abscess or fistula formation

Treatment:

  1. Massage & Topical Antibiotics: Mainstay treatment, effective in 90% of infants by 6-9 months.
  2. Lacrimal Syringing: Done with saline/antibiotic solution if not cured by 3 months. Helps open membranous occlusion.
  3. Probing (Bowman’s Probe): Performed if unresolved by 6 months (or 9-12 months in some cases). Often one probing is sufficient.
  4. Balloon Catheter Dilation: For cases unresponsive to probing, helps in scarring or constriction.
  5. Intubation with Silicone Tube: For failures of probing or balloon dilation, kept for 6 months.
  6. Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR): If treatment fails by age 4, DCR surgery is performed.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Congenital glaucoma (Causes photophobia and watering of eyes)

  • Congenital glaucoma presents with triad of epiphora (excessive tearing), photophobia, and blepharospasm (eyelid spasm).
  • It results from increased intraocular pressure (IOP) due to impaired aqueous humor drainage.
  • Other features: Enlarged cornea (buphthalmos), corneal haze, and increased cup-to-disc ratio.

Choice C: Congenital entropion (Can cause reflex tearing and photophobia)

  • Congenital entropion is a malpositioning of the eyelid, leading to inward turning of the eyelid margin.
  • The eyelashes rub against the cornea, causing irritation, reflex tearing, and photophobia.

Choice D: Congenital distichiasis (Can cause photophobia and watering due to extra eyelashes rubbing against the cornea)

  • Congenital distichiasis is a rare condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows from the meibomian glands.
  • These extra lashes can irritate the cornea, leading to tearing, photophobia, and discomfort.

Key Takeaway:

The only option that does NOT cause photophobia is Congenital nasolacrimal duct blockage (Choice B). The other conditions directly affect the cornea, leading to light sensitivity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male comes with a sudden onset of flashes. He wears thick glasses since early childhood. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Rhegmatogenous (Primary) Retinal Detachment

Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment occurs when a retinal tear allows subretinal fluid to accumulate, separating the retina from the underlying pigment epithelium. It is the most common type of retinal detachment.

Predisposing Factors:

  • Age: More common in individuals aged 40-60 years.
  • Sex: More frequent in males (3:2).
  • Myopia: Affects about 40% of cases.
  • Aphakia/Pseudophakia: More common in eyes without natural lenses.
  • Retinal Degenerations: Lattice degeneration, snail track degeneration, and more.
  • Trauma: Can be a contributing factor.
  • Posterior Vitreous Detachment (PVD): Associated with 10% of cases.

Pathogenesis:
Vitreoretinal traction from rapid eye movements and conditions like PVD or myopia can cause retinal breaks. Fluid from the liquefied vitreous leaks through these breaks, creating a retinal separation.

Clinical Features:

  • Prodromal Symptoms: Floaters and flashes of light (photopsia).
  • Symptoms:
    • Gradual peripheral vision loss, progressing to central vision loss.
    • Sudden appearance of a dark cloud or veil.
    • Sudden, painless vision loss in extensive detachments.
  • Signs:
    • Relative afferent pupillary defect.
    • Altered red reflex seen during ophthalmoscopy.
    • Retinal breaks may be detected at the retinal periphery.
    • Vitreous pigments (tobacco dusting) may be visible.
    • Electroretinography shows subnormal or absent readings.

Complications:

  • Proliferative vitreoretinopathy (PVR)
  • Cataracts
  • Uveitis
  • Phthisis bulbi

Treatment:

  1. Sealing of Retinal Breaks: Cryocoagulation or photocoagulation.
  2. Drainage of Subretinal Fluid (SRF): Performed to reattach the retina.
  3. Maintenance of Retinal Apposition:
    • Scleral Buckling: Indentation of the sclera to apply pressure.
    • Pneumatic Retinopexy: Gas bubble injection to seal the tear.
    • Pars Plana Vitrectomy: Removal of vitreous, followed by endolaser photocoagulation and tamponade with gas or silicone oil.

Prophylaxis:
Laser photocoagulation or cryotherapy can prevent detachment in high-risk individuals (e.g., those with myopia, aphakia, or retinal detachment in the fellow eye).

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) (Painless, sudden loss of vision but no flashes)

  • CRAO presents with sudden, profound, painless vision loss, often described as "a curtain coming down."
  • Fundoscopy shows a cherry-red spot at the macula and a pale retina.
  • Flashes (photopsia) are NOT a characteristic symptom.

Choice C: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) (Gradual vision loss with blood and thunder fundus, no flashes)

  • CRVO presents with gradual vision loss due to retinal ischemia and hemorrhage.
  • Fundoscopy shows a "blood and thunder" appearance with tortuous veins, hemorrhages, and macular edema.
  • Flashes are not a typical symptom.

Choice D: Vitreous Hemorrhage (Floaters and blurry vision, but not primarily flashes)

  • Vitreous hemorrhage presents with sudden floaters and blurred vision.
  • Common causes include diabetic retinopathy, trauma, or retinal tears, but it does not primarily cause flashes.

Key Takeaway:

The most likely cause of flashes (photopsia) in a highly myopic patient is rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (Choice A: RD), which requires urgent evaluation and treatment to prevent permanent vision loss.

questions.text: An old man came with a painful red eye since 1 day. Cornea was Edematous with cataract. IOP was high = 50 mmhg, in the affected eye with a deep AC. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Phacolytic Glaucoma (Lens Protein Glaucoma)

Pathogenesis:
This is a secondary open-angle glaucoma caused by lens proteins, macrophages, and inflammatory debris obstructing the trabecular meshwork. The lens proteins leak from a hypermature cataractous lens through an intact capsule, leading to blockage.

Clinical Features:

  • Acute rise in intraocular pressure (IOP) resembling acute congestive glaucoma.
  • The anterior chamber may appear deep, with fine white protein particles in the aqueous humor, forming a pseudohypopyon.
  • Gonioscopy reveals an open anterior chamber angle.

Management:

  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract with posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL) implantation.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Phacomorphic Glaucoma (Shallow AC, pupillary block, and narrow angles)

  • Caused by lens swelling in an intumescent cataract, leading to pupillary block and angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Key differences:
    • Anterior chamber is shallow (vs. deep in phacolytic glaucoma).
    • IOP is high, but due to angle closure, not trabecular blockage by lens proteins.

Choice C: Malignant Glaucoma (Aqueous Misdirection Syndrome) (Shallow AC with normal lens, post-surgery complication)

  • Usually follows intraocular surgery (e.g., cataract or glaucoma surgery).
  • Key differences:
    • Shallow anterior chamber (AC) in both phakic and pseudophakic eyes.
    • Normal or small-sized lens, unlike cataractous lenses in phacolytic glaucoma.

Choice D: Fuch’s Heterochromic Iridocyclitis (FHI) (Mild, chronic uveitis, with normal or slightly raised IOP)

  • Key differences:
    • IOP is mildly elevated, not as high as 50 mmHg.
    • Chronic, painless, low-grade inflammation (vs. acute, painful glaucoma in phacolytic).
    • Heterochromia of the iris, stellate KPs, and no synechiae formation.

Key Takeaway:

The most common cause of acute red eye with high IOP (50 mmHg), corneal edema, a deep AC, and a hypermature cataract is Phacolytic Glaucoma (Choice A).

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about this condition if a patient has night blindness. Picture of retinitis pigmentosa red in color
questions.solution:
Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP)

Retinitis pigmentosa (RP) is a hereditary disorder that primarily affects the rods in the retina, leading to progressive vision loss.

Inheritance:

  • Sporadic: Mutation in over 50 genes, including rhodopsin gene (40%).
  • Inherited:
    • Autosomal Recessive (AR): Most common (25%), moderate severity.
    • Autosomal Dominant (AD): Less common (25%), milder form.
    • X-linked (XL): Least common (10%), most severe.

Prevalence and Demographics:

  • Prevalence: 1 in 5,000 individuals worldwide.
  • Age: Typically presents in childhood, progressing slowly to blindness in middle age.
  • Sex: Males more affected (3:2).
  • Laterality: Almost always bilateral, both eyes affected equally.

Pathogenesis:
RP is characterized by the death of rod photoreceptors, although the exact mechanism is unclear. Cone photoreceptors deteriorate later in the disease.

Clinical Features:

  1. Visual Symptoms:
    • Night Blindness: Early sign, due to rod degeneration.
    • Dark Adaptation: Increased light threshold in peripheral retina.
    • Tubular Vision: Loss of peripheral vision, central vision preserved in advanced stages.
    • Central Vision Loss: Occurs over time.
  2. Fundus Changes:
    • Pigmentary Changes: Black spots around retinal veins.
    • Arteriolar Narrowing: In later stages, retinal vessels become thread-like.
    • Atrophy of Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE): Seen in peripheral retina.
    • Optic Disc Pallor: Eventually leads to optic atrophy.
  3. Visual Field Changes:
    • Annular Scotoma: Ring-shaped blind spot, expanding as the disease progresses.
  4. Electrophysiological Changes:
    • Electroretinogram (ERG): Initially subnormal, eventually extinguished.
    • Electro-oculogram (EOG): Subnormal with absence of light peak.

Associations:

  • Ocular: Myopia, open-angle glaucoma, microphthalmos, keratoconus, posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Systemic: About 25% of cases have associated conditions such as:
    • Laurence-Moon-Biedl Syndrome: RP, obesity, hypogenitalism, polydactyly, mental retardation.
    • Usher's Syndrome: RP with labyrinthine deafness.
    • Cockayne's Syndrome: RP, progressive deafness, dwarfism, ataxia.
    • Other syndromes: Hallgren’s, Refsum’s, Friedreich’s ataxia, etc.

Atypical Forms:

  • Cone-Rod Dystrophy: Cones degenerate first, affecting central vision and color perception.
  • RP Sine Pigmento: RP without visible pigmentary changes.
  • Sectorial RP: Affects only one sector of the retina.
  • Pericentric RP: Pigmentary changes around the macula.
  • Retinitis Punctata Albescens: White dots on fundus without pigment changes.

Treatment:

  • No effective treatment, but options include:
    1. Vasodilators, placental extracts, light exclusion, and ultrasonic therapy have been tried, but with limited success.
    2. Vitamin A (15,000 IU daily) may slow progression.
    3. Correct refractive errors with glasses.
    4. Acetazolamide for cystoid macular edema.
    5. Low Vision Aids (magnifying glasses, night vision devices).
    6. Genetic Counseling: To reduce incidence through non-consanguineous marriages and family planning.

Prophylaxis:

  • Genetic counseling and advice on family planning for affected individuals.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Late presentation is constriction of the visual field (Correct Statement)

  • Progressive peripheral vision loss (tunnel vision) occurs late in RP.
  • Begins as an annular scotoma that expands inward, leading to "tubular vision."
  • Central vision is typically preserved until the advanced stages.

Choice C: ERG - A and B wave amplitude (Correct Statement)

  • Electroretinography (ERG) shows reduced A and B wave amplitudes.
  • Early stages: Subnormal ERG responses.
  • Late stages: ERG becomes extinguished as photoreceptors degenerate completely.

Choice D: Rods are more commonly affected than cones (Correct Statement)

  • RP primarily affects rods first, leading to night blindness and peripheral vision loss.
  • Cones degenerate later, causing central vision loss and color vision impairment in advanced cases.

Key Takeaway:

The incorrect statement is Choice A ("Night blindness is a late feature"). Night blindness is an early symptom of Retinitis Pigmentosa due to rod photoreceptor degeneration.

questions.text: A man working at a construction site comes with red eye. There is a history of chuna particle fall 1 hour back. What will be the first line of management?
questions.solution:
Chemical Injuries

Chemical injuries can range from minor irritation to complete loss of vision, with the severity dependent on the type of chemical and its exposure duration.

Causes
Chemical injuries typically result from:

  1. Domestic accidents (e.g., ammonia, solvents, cosmetics)
  2. Agricultural accidents (e.g., fertilizers, insecticides)
  3. Laboratory accidents (e.g., acids, alkalis)
  4. Deliberate attacks (e.g., acid attacks)
  5. Chemical warfare
  6. Self-inflicted injuries (e.g., in malingerers)

Types of Chemical Injuries

  • Alkali Burns: The most severe, caused by substances like lime, caustic soda, and ammonia. They cause deep tissue penetration, resulting in widespread necrosis and difficulty in circumscribing damage. The stages include:
    1. Acute Ischemic Necrosis: Conjunctival edema, corneal sloughing, iris inflammation.
    2. Reparation: Regeneration of conjunctival and corneal epithelium.
    3. Complications: Symblepharon, corneal ulceration, cataract, and glaucoma.
  • Acid Burns: Less severe but still dangerous, caused by sulfuric, hydrochloric, or nitric acids. Acid burns cause protein coagulation, creating a protective barrier.
    • Conjunctival necrosis, sloughing, and symblepharon formation occur.
    • Corneal damage ranges from opacification to potential corneal sloughing.

Grading of Chemical Burns (Roper-Hall Classification)

  • Grade I: Clear cornea, no limbal ischemia – Excellent prognosis
  • Grade II: Hazy cornea, iris visible, <1/3 limbal ischemia – Good prognosis
  • Grade III: Opaque cornea, iris obscured, 1/3 to 1/2 limbal ischemia – Guarded prognosis
  • Grade IV: Opaque cornea, no iris view, >1/2 limbal ischemia – Poor prognosis

Treatment of Chemical Burns

  1. Immediate Actions:
    • Irrigation: Flush the eye with clean water or saline for 20-30 minutes until pH normalizes.
    • Remove Contaminants: Use a swab stick to remove particles, especially from lime.
    • Excise Necrotic Tissue: Remove damaged conjunctiva and corneal epithelium.
  2. Maintenance:
    • Topical Antibiotics (e.g., moxifloxacin) to prevent infection.
    • Steroid Eye Drops (with caution after 2 weeks) to reduce inflammation.
    • Cycloplegics (e.g., atropine) for comfort.
    • Ascorbic Acid to improve wound healing.
    • Lubricant Eye Drops to promote healing.
    • Autologous Serum for epithelial healing and growth factors.
    • Sodium Citrate to stabilize neutrophils and reduce collagenase.
    • Doxycycline for collagenase inhibition.
  3. Prevention of Complications:
    • Symblepharon Prevention: Use a glass shell or sweep a glass rod in the fornices twice daily.
    • Secondary Glaucoma: Treated with timolol and acetazolamide.
    • Limbal Stem Cell Deficiency: Managed with amniotic membrane transplantation.
    • Corneal Opacity: Consider keratoplasty if stem cells are adequate.
    • Keratoprosthesis: For severely damaged eyes when keratoplasty isn't possible.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Antibiotics (Not the first step)

  • Antibiotics (e.g., moxifloxacin) are used later to prevent secondary infections.
  • However, irrigation comes first to remove the chemical agent before administering antibiotics.

Choice C: Patch eye (Incorrect management)

  • Eye patching is contraindicated in chemical burns because it traps residual chemicals and increases corneal damage.
  • Instead, lubricants and frequent irrigation help with healing.

Choice D: Tarsorrhaphy (Not the first step)

  • Tarsorrhaphy (surgical eyelid closure) is a late-stage treatment for severe burns with limbal stem cell deficiency.
  • It is not an emergency intervention and is only considered in chronic non-healing ulcers.

Key Takeaway:

The first-line management for chemical injuries (such as lime burns) is immediate and prolonged saline irrigation(Choice A). This prevents further ocular damage by neutralizing the chemical and flushing it out.

choices.text: Difference in vision of two eyes
Difference in size of pupil of both eyes

questions.solution:
Anisometropia

Anisometropia refers to a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive power between the two eyes. This can occur in varying degrees and may result in visual discomfort, depending on the severity of the refractive difference.

Clinical Features:

  • Refractive Difference: In anisometropia, the two eyes have differing refractive errors (e.g., one eye may be nearsighted, and the other farsighted). A slight refractive difference is common, but in severe cases, the discrepancy can be significant.
  • Binocular Vision: In mild cases (low-grade anisometropia), the individual can maintain binocular vision, though the fusion of images may not be perfect, leading to asthenopic symptoms (eye strain, fatigue).
  • Eye Strain: When the difference is smaller, binocular vision is possible but may still cause symptoms like headaches, eye fatigue, and discomfort due to the effort required for the brain to fuse the images.
  • Higher Grades (≥2.5 D): When the anisometropia exceeds 2.5 diopters, fusion of the images becomes difficult or impossible. In such cases, vision may become uniocular (one-eyed vision). This can lead to amblyopia (lazy eye) in children, particularly in the weaker eye, which may also become divergent (strabismus).
  • Amblyopia Risk: In young children, if one eye is not used adequately (due to severe anisometropia), the eye may become amblyopic over time, causing permanent visual impairment in that eye.

Treatment:

Correcting anisometropia can be challenging, as the refractive difference between the eyes may cause discomfort and visual difficulties. Several approaches can be used to manage this condition:

  1. Spectacle Lenses:
    • Concave Lenses: These reduce the size of the retinal image, which could make the image in one eye smaller than the other.
    • Convex Lenses: These enlarge the retinal image, possibly causing the image in one eye to be larger than the other.
    • Challenges with Spectacles: In high degrees of anisometropia (such as in cases of unilateral aphakia), the difference in retinal image size between the two eyes can lead to aniseikonia (perceptual distortion due to differing image sizes). This may make it difficult for the brain to fuse the images, leading to visual discomfort and straining.
    • Prismatic Effect and Distortion: Looking obliquely through corrective lenses can create different prismatic effects and distortions in the two eyes, further increasing discomfort and making regular spectacle use problematic.
  2. Compromise Correction:
    • When full correction cannot be tolerated, a compromise approach may be used where each eye is undercorrected to some extent. This minimizes the disparity between the images produced by each eye but may not fully resolve the anisometropia.
    • Size-Lenses (Iseikonic Lenses):
    • Specialized iseikonic lenses are designed to reduce the size difference between the retinal images in the two eyes. These lenses are customized and have a specific optical construction to correct for aniseikonia. However, the clinical outcomes with iseikonic lenses are often disappointing, and they may not always provide a perfect solution.
  3. Contact Lenses:
    • Contact lenses can be beneficial because they reduce the optical distortions and image size differences that occur with spectacles. They may be a good option in certain cases where spectacle lenses are not comfortable or effective.
  4. Monovision or Uniocular Vision:
    • In some cases, monovision (where one eye is used for distance vision and the other for near vision) or uniocular vision (where only one eye is used at a time) may be a viable solution. Over time, people may adapt to this practice, as is common in situations like using a uniocular microscope or monocle. This approach works particularly well when one eye is nearly emmetropic (normal vision) and the other is myopic (nearsighted), allowing for distance vision with one eye and near vision with the other, without the need for glasses.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Difference in vision of two eyes (Incorrect)

  • While anisometropia can lead to differences in vision quality between the two eyes, the term specifically refers to a refractive error difference, not just vision quality differences due to other causes (e.g., cataract, retinal diseases).

Choice C: Difference in size of pupil of both eyes (Incorrect)

  • Unequal pupil sizes refer to anisocoria, not anisometropia. Anisocoria is associated with neurological or autonomic disorders, such as Horner’s syndrome or Adie’s tonic pupil.

Choice D: Difference in size of eyeball (Incorrect)

  • Eyeball size variations can be seen in axial myopia or hyperopia, but anisometropia does not necessarily involve a difference in eyeball size. It specifically relates to differences in refractive error, not anatomical size differences.

Key Takeaway:

Anisometropia is defined as a significant difference in refractive error between the two eyes (Choice A), which can lead to difficulty in binocular vision, amblyopia, or visual discomfort.

questions.text: All are actions of superior oblique except
questions.solution:
Extraocular Muscles of the Eye

The six extraocular muscles control eye movements: 4 rectus muscles (superior, inferior, medial, and lateral) and 2 oblique muscles (superior and inferior). Their origin, insertion, nerve supply, and actions determine their unique roles in ocular motility.

Origin and Insertion

Rectus Muscles

  • Origin: Common tendinous ring (annulus of Zinn) at the apex of the orbit.
    • Medial Rectus (MR): Medial part of the ring.
    • Superior Rectus (SR): Superior part and adjoining dura covering the optic nerve.
    • Inferior Rectus (IR): Inferior part of the ring.
    • Lateral Rectus (LR): Lateral part of the ring, originating from two heads forming a "V."
  • Insertion: Into the sclera at specific distances from the limbus:
    • Medial Rectus: 5.5 mm.
    • Inferior Rectus: 6.5 mm.
    • Lateral Rectus: 6.9 mm.
    • Superior Rectus: 7.7 mm.

Oblique Muscles

  • Superior Oblique (SO):
    • Origin: Bone above and medial to the optic foramina.
    • Insertion: Upper and outer sclera behind the equator.
    • Path: Runs forward, loops around a pulley (trochlea), and redirects posteriorly.
  • Inferior Oblique (IO):
    • Origin: Orbital plate of the maxilla, lateral to the nasolacrimal duct.
    • Insertion: Lower and outer sclera behind the equator.
    • Path: Passes laterally and backward.

Nerve Supply

  • Oculomotor Nerve (Cranial Nerve III): Supplies:
    • Superior Rectus (SR).
    • Medial Rectus (MR).
    • Inferior Rectus (IR).
    • Inferior Oblique (IO).
  • Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): Supplies Superior Oblique (SO).
  • Abducent Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): Supplies Lateral Rectus (LR).

Actions

Axial Movement

  • Vertical Axis:
    • Medial Rectus: Adduction (moves eye inward).
    • Lateral Rectus: Abduction (moves eye outward).
  • Horizontal Axis:
    • Superior Rectus: Elevation (moves eye upward).
    • Inferior Rectus: Depression (moves eye downward).
  • Anteroposterior Axis (torsion/rotation):
    • Superior Oblique: Intorsion (rotates top of eye inward).
    • Inferior Oblique: Extorsion (rotates top of eye outward).

Main and Subsidiary Actions

  • Muscles with angles to the optical axis (SR, IR, SO, IO) have subsidiary actions:
    • Superior Rectus: Elevation (primary), Intorsion, Adduction.
    • Inferior Rectus: Depression (primary), Extorsion, Adduction.
    • Superior Oblique: Intorsion (primary), Depression, Abduction.
    • Inferior Oblique: Extorsion (primary), Elevation, Abduction.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: All are features of third nerve palsy except
questions.solution:
Paralysis of the Third Cranial Nerve (Oculomotor Nerve Palsy)

The third cranial nerve palsy is a common condition that may be congenital or acquired. It leads to several clinical features that are important for diagnosis.

Clinical Features:

  1. Ptosis: The upper eyelid is drooping due to the paralysis of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) muscle, which is responsible for lifting the eyelid.
  2. Deviation: The affected eyeball is typically turned downward, outward, and slightly intorted. This happens because the lateral rectus (controlled by the abducent nerve) and the superior oblique (controlled by the trochlear nerve) muscles are unopposed, leading to the abnormal position of the eye.
  3. Restricted Ocular Movements: All movements of the affected eye are restricted except for outward movement (abduction), as the lateral rectus is still functional.
  4. Pupil Changes:
    • The pupil is fixed (unable to constrict in response to light) and dilated due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae muscle, which controls constriction of the pupil.
  5. Accommodation Loss: The ability to accommodate (focus on near objects) is completely lost due to the paralysis of the ciliary muscle, which is responsible for changing the shape of the lens for near vision.
  6. Diplopia (Double Vision): Crossed diplopia is commonly seen when the eyelid is raised. The misalignment of the eyes causes images to be perceived at different angles, leading to double vision.
  7. Altered Head Posture: The patient may adopt an abnormal head posture to compensate for the misalignment and to improve the visual appearance, especially if the pupil remains dilated and the eye movements are impaired.

Etiology:

The third cranial nerve palsy can be caused by various conditions, such as:

  • Aneurysms (especially of the posterior communicating artery)
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Trauma
  • Tumors
  • Infections
  • Congenital anomalies (in cases of developmental issues)

In cases of acquired third nerve palsy, it’s important to investigate for serious underlying conditions like aneurysms, particularly when pupil involvement is present, as this can indicate a compressive lesion.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Ptosis (Correct Feature of Third Nerve Palsy)

  • The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, which lifts the eyelid, is paralyzed, leading to ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

Choice B: Exotropia and Hypotropia (Correct Feature of Third Nerve Palsy)

  • The lateral rectus (VI nerve) and superior oblique (IV nerve) remain functional, pulling the eye outward (exotropia) and downward (hypotropia).

Choice D: Pupillary Dilation (Correct Feature of Third Nerve Palsy)

  • The parasympathetic fibers traveling with the third nerve control pupil constriction.
  • In a compressive third nerve palsy (e.g., due to an aneurysm), these fibers are affected, causing a fixed, dilated pupil (mydriasis).

Key Takeaway:

Third nerve palsy presents with ptosis, pupillary dilation, and exotropia with hypotropia, but abduction is preserved. Therefore, the incorrect feature is "Limited Abduction" (Choice C).

questions.text: A patient with rheumatic heart disease presents with a superior visual field defect in the right eye since one day. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO)

Branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO) occurs when an embolus lodges in a branch of the retinal artery, most commonly at a bifurcation point. This blockage can lead to retinal ischemia and various visual disturbances.

Clinical Features of BRAO:

  • Oedema in the Retina: The area of the retina distal to the occlusion becomes edematous (swollen) due to impaired blood flow.
  • Narrowing of Arterioles: The arterioles in the affected area may become constricted, further hindering blood flow.
  • Atrophy: Over time, the affected retinal area may undergo atrophy (degeneration), leading to permanent damage.
  • Sectoral Visual Field Defect: The visual field loss typically presents as a sectoral defect corresponding to the occluded area of the retina.

Management of BRAO:

Management focuses on preserving retinal function and addressing the underlying cause. However, once significant damage has occurred, recovery is often limited.

Treatment for Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO):

Since BRAO is a form of retinal artery occlusion, many of the same principles used for central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO) are applied. However, it is important to note that retinal tissue can only survive ischemia for a short time (90–100 minutes).

  1. Immediate Lowering of Intraocular Pressure (IOP): Reducing IOP can help improve blood flow to the retina and may assist in dislodging the embolus:
    • Intermittent ocular massage: Helps in potentially dislodging the embolus.
    • Intravenous mannitol: A diuretic that can help lower IOP.
    • Paracentesis: Removal of a small amount of fluid from the anterior chamber of the eye to lower IOP.
    • Intravenous acetazolamide (500 mg): Administered immediately to lower IOP.
  2. Vasodilators and Oxygen Therapy:
    • Vasodilators: May help to alleviate any spasm in the retinal arteries.
    • Inhalation of 5% carbon dioxide and 95% oxygen: This mixture may help to reduce vasospasm and improve oxygen supply to the retina. Practically, this is achieved by having the patient breathe into a polythene bag.
  3. Fibrinolytic Therapy: In some cases, fibrinolytic agents (medications that break down clots) may help if the occlusion is due to a thrombus or embolus.
  4. Intravenous Steroids: Indicated in cases associated with giant cell arteritis, which can lead to inflammation of the blood vessels supplying the retina.
  5. Laser Photodisruption: Laser therapy can be used in selected cases to break up the embolus and potentially improve retinal perfusion.

Systemic Work-Up:

After the emergency management of BRAO or CRAO, it's crucial to investigate underlying systemic conditions that could have contributed to the occlusion. These may include conditions like hypertension, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia.

Complications of Retinal Artery Occlusion:

One potential complication is the development of neovascular glaucoma (NVG). This condition may occur as a delayed complication, with an incidence rate ranging from 2% to 6% in patients who have experienced CRAO or BRAO. NVG involves the growth of abnormal new blood vessels in the eye, which can lead to increased IOP and further damage to the optic nerve.

Prognosis:

The prognosis for BRAO largely depends on the duration of ischemia and the effectiveness of treatment. Unfortunately, once retinal tissue has been deprived of oxygen for too long, irreversible damage can occur. Early intervention can help improve outcomes, but full recovery of vision is not always possible.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Central Retinal Vein Occlusion (CRVO) (Incorrect)

  • CRVO typically presents with diffuse retinal hemorrhages and "blood and thunder" appearance.
  • Presents with sudden painless vision loss rather than a sectoral visual field defect.

Choice B: Central Retinal Artery Occlusion (CRAO) (Incorrect)

  • CRAO causes complete or near-total vision loss rather than a sectoral defect.
  • Fundus findings include cherry-red spot at the macula and a pale retina.

Choice C: Branch Retinal Vein Occlusion (BRVO) (Incorrect)

  • BRVO presents with retinal hemorrhages along the occluded vein's distribution, not with ischemic whitening as seen in BRAO.
  • More common in hypertensive and diabetic patients rather than those with rheumatic heart disease.

Key Takeaway:

Branch Retinal Artery Occlusion (BRAO) (Choice D) is the most likely cause in a patient with rheumatic heart disease presenting with a superior visual field defect.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of proposis in middle-aged people
questions.solution:
Proptosis

Proptosis is defined as the forward displacement of the eyeball beyond the orbital margins. While exophthalmos is often used interchangeably with proptosis, it is customarily reserved for the displacement associated with thyroid eye disease.

Classification of Proptosis:

Proptosis can be classified into the following categories based on clinical features:

  • Unilateral Proptosis: Protrusion of one eye.
  • Bilateral Proptosis: Protrusion of both eyes.
  • Acute Proptosis: Rapid onset of proptosis.
  • Intermittent Proptosis: Proptosis that appears and disappears spontaneously.
  • Pulsating Proptosis: Proptosis with rhythmic, pulsatile movement, often due to vascular causes.

Etiology (Causes of Proptosis):

A. Causes of Unilateral Proptosis:

  1. Congenital Conditions:
    • Dermoid cyst
    • Congenital cystic eyeball
    • Orbital teratoma
  2. Traumatic Lesions:
    • Orbital hemorrhage
    • Retained intraorbital foreign body
    • Traumatic aneurysm
    • Orbital emphysema
  3. Inflammatory Lesions:
    • Acute inflammation such as orbital cellulitis, abscess, thrombophlebitis, panophthalmitis, and cavernous sinus thrombosis (this often starts as unilateral but may become bilateral).
    • Chronic inflammatory lesions like pseudotumors, tuberculoma, gumma, and sarcoidosis.
  4. Circulatory Disturbances and Vascular Lesions:
    • Angioneurotic edema
    • Orbital varix (venous malformation)
    • Orbital aneurysms
  5. Cysts of the Orbit:
    • Hematic cyst
    • Implantation cyst
    • Parasitic cysts (hydatid cyst and cysticercus cellulosae)
  6. Orbital Tumors:
    • Primary, secondary, or metastatic tumors (e.g., from breast or lung cancer).
  7. Mucoceles of Paranasal Sinuses:
    • Especially common in the frontal sinus (most common), ethmoidal, and maxillary sinuses.

Note:

  • The most common cause of unilateral proptosis in children is orbital cellulitis.
  • The most common cause of unilateral proptosis in adults is thyroid ophthalmopathy.

B. Causes of Bilateral Proptosis:

  1. Developmental Anomalies:
    • Craniofacial dysostosis, such as oxycephaly (tower skull).
  2. Osteopathies:
    • Osteitis deformans (Paget's disease)
    • Rickets
    • Acromegaly
  3. Inflammatory Conditions:
    • Mikulicz's syndrome
    • Late stage of cavernous sinus thrombosis
  4. Endocrinal Exophthalmos:
    • Thyrotoxicosis (hyperthyroidism) or thyroid-related exophthalmos.
  5. Tumors:
    • Symmetrical lymphoma or lymphosarcoma
    • Secondary tumors from neuroblastoma, nephroblastoma, Ewing's sarcoma, or leukemia.
  6. Systemic Diseases:
    • Histiocytosis
    • Systemic amyloidosis
    • Xanthomatosis
    • Wegener's granulomatosis

Note:

  • The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in adults is thyroid ophthalmopathy.
  • The most common cause of bilateral proptosis in children is neuroblastoma and leukemia (chloroma).

C. Causes of Acute Proptosis:

Acute proptosis develops very rapidly, with sudden onset. Common causes include:

  1. Orbital Emphysema (air within the orbit).
  2. Fracture of the Medial Orbital Wall.
  3. Orbital Hemorrhage.
  4. Rupture of an Ethmoidal Mucocele.

D. Causes of Intermittent Proptosis:

This form of proptosis comes and goes spontaneously. The causes include:

  1. Orbital Varix (venous malformation).
  2. Periodic Orbital Edema.
  3. Recurrent Orbital Hemorrhage.
  4. Highly Vascular Tumors.

Most Important Cause:

  • Orbital Varix, where proptosis develops intermittently and rapidly when venous stasis is induced by activities such as:
    • Forward bending or lowering the head.
    • Turning the head forcefully.
    • Hyperextension of the neck.
    • Coughing.
    • Forced expiration.
    • Pressure on the jugular veins (e.g., compression of nostrils).

E. Causes of Pulsatile Proptosis:

Pulsatile proptosis occurs due to vascular lesions that cause pulsations to be transmitted to the orbit. Causes include:

  1. Carotid-Cavernous Fistula (abnormal connection between the carotid artery and cavernous sinus).
  2. Saccular Aneurysm of the Ophthalmic Artery (a balloon-like bulge in the artery).
  3. Transmitted Cerebral Pulsations:
  • Conditions with a deficient orbital roof, such as:
    • Congenital meningocele or meningoencephalocele.
    • Neurofibromatosis
    • Traumatic or operative hiatus (i.e., damage to the orbital roof during trauma or surgery).

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice B: Hemangioma (Incorrect)

  • Capillary hemangioma is the most common orbital tumor in children, not middle-aged adults.
  • Cavernous hemangiomas are common in adults but typically cause slowly progressive, painless proptosis, not the most frequent cause.

Choice C: Meningioma (Incorrect)

  • Orbital meningiomas are rare compared to thyroid eye disease.
  • Typically seen in middle-aged women but grow slowly and are often associated with optic nerve compressionrather than significant proptosis.

Choice D: Optic Glioma (Incorrect)

  • Most common in children, particularly in neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1).
  • Causes gradual visual loss with mild proptosis, unlike the more prominent proptosis seen in thyroid eye disease.

Key Takeaway:

Thyroid Ophthalmopathy (Graves' Disease) (Choice A) is the most common cause of proptosis in middle-aged individuals.

questions.text: A patient has paralysis of orbicularis muscle, lagophthalmos and loss of sensation in cornea leading to blindness. Which of the following can be a cause
questions.solution:
Leprosy (Hansen's Disease)

Leprosy, or Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the acid-fast bacillus Mycobacterium leprae, which is similar to the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis. It primarily affects the skin, superficial nerves, nose, and throat, and approximately one-third of patients experience complications involving the eyes.

Types of Leprosy:

  1. Lepromatous Leprosy (Cutaneous Type):
    • Characterized by depressed cellular immunity and often direct involvement of the eyes.
    • The disease is more severe, with early and widespread ocular involvement, which may cause neuroparalytic and neurotrophic keratopathy (refer to Chapter 15 for further details).
    • The eyes are typically involved later in the disease. Initial symptoms include:
      • Superficial infections such as conjunctivitis, episcleritis, and keratitis.
      • Uveitis, which may lead to visual loss due to:
        • Corneal opacities
        • Lens opacities
        • Non-reacting small pupils
        • Iris atrophy
    • The tissues of the eye in lepromatous leprosy are heavily infected with leprosy bacilli. There may also be the formation of erythema nodosum leprosum (skin papules containing antigen-antibody complexes). These papules indicate immune complex deposition, which may contribute to iridocyclitis (inflammation of the iris and ciliary body).
  2. Tuberculoid Leprosy (Neural Type):
    • Characterized by good cell-mediated immunity and a more systemic resistance.
    • Uveitis is rare in tuberculoid leprosy. When it occurs, it may result from the spread of the infection along the ciliary nerves or from extension of more frequent corneal involvement.
    • Bacilli are sparse, and antibody formation is usually inconspicuous.
    • The disease is marked by the formation of granulomas, which may surround peripheral nerves, leading to:
      • Neuroparalytic lagophthalmos (inability to close the eyelids properly due to facial nerve involvement).
      • Severe exposure keratopathy resulting from facial nerve involvement.
    • Neurotrophic keratopathy may develop due to the loss of protective mechanisms in the cornea from the involvement of the trigeminal nerve.

Ocular Involvement:

  • Lepromatous leprosy tends to affect the eyes later in the disease, while the tuberculoid form has less frequent ocular involvement.
  • Common complications in the eye include:
    • Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, and keratitis in the early stages.
    • Uveitis, corneal opacities, and lens opacities.
    • In severe cases, patients may develop iridocyclitis as part of an immune response.

Treatment of Leprosy:

The standard treatment of leprosy in adults typically involves a combination of antibiotics, with the primary drug being:

  • Dapsone (50–100 mg daily), a member of the sulphone group.

Other medications that may be used in combination with dapsone include:

  • Rifampicin
  • Ofloxacin
  • Clofazimine
  • Minocycline

These antibiotics help to control the infection and prevent further complications, including those affecting the eyes.

Incorrect Choices Explanation:

Choice A: Trachoma (Incorrect)

  • Caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes A–C).
  • Leads to conjunctival scarring, trichiasis (inward turning eyelashes), and corneal opacification, but does not cause facial nerve paralysis or lagophthalmos.

Choice C: Ophthalmia Neonatorum (Incorrect)

  • Neonatal conjunctivitis, caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, or other bacteria.
  • Can cause severe purulent conjunctivitis, corneal ulceration, and blindness, but does not involve cranial nerve paralysis.

Choice D: Lyme Disease (Incorrect)

  • Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted via Ixodes ticks.
  • Can cause facial nerve palsy (Bell’s palsy), but corneal anesthesia and neurotrophic keratopathy are rare.

Key Takeaway:

Leprosy (Choice B) is the most likely cause, as it leads to facial nerve paralysis (lagophthalmos) and trigeminal nerve involvement (corneal anesthesia), resulting in blindness.
